title: American_Top_40_1980_February_9th
description:
"Every week on American Top 40 we count down the biggest hits in the USA from Cool Ridge, West Virginia, to Coolspring, Pennsylvania; from Cool Valley, Missouri, to Coolville, Ohio, and at number 37, here's Kool & The Gang with 'Ladies' Night'."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This recording is a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this countdown:

Newcomer Pat Benetar debuts with her first chart hit, "Heartbreaker" (at number 40), and Pink Floyd debuts only the second chart hit in their 15 year career, "Another Brick In The Wall Part Two" (at number 32).

A listener wants to know if any song has ever hit number one on the pop, soul, and country charts. Casey says it has happened only twice, and both times were in the 50's.

Casey recalls how the greatest recording act in history was once so unsure of its own popularity that, in a rock band popularity poll, its members became involved in election fraud by writing in hundreds of fake votes for themselves.

One unknown but hopeful teenager once turned down contracts from four major record companies because they wouldn't agree to his terms. His first hit is in this countdown.

A listener wants to know what the biggest selling live album in the rock era has been. Casey says this particular album was by a solo performer who was not a superstar when he released it.

Casey gives a special report on the musical style "Rockabilly" and the latest Rockabilly song to make the chart. It's in the top 10.

LW#3: Coward Of The County - Kenny Rogers
LW#2: Do That To Me One More Time - The Captain & Tennille
LW#1: Rock With You - Michael Jackson
